case_vignette: A 49-YEAR-OLD MAN COMES TO THE PHYSICIAN BECAUSE OF TENDER, RED NODULES THAT APPEARED ON HIS CHEST 3 DAYS AGO. THREE WEEKS AGO, HE HAD SIMILAR SYMPTOMS IN HIS RIGHT LOWER LIMB AND ANOTHER EPISODE IN HIS LEFT FOOT; BOTH EPISODES RESOLVED SPONTANEOUSLY. HE ALSO HAS DIARRHEA AND HAS HAD A POOR APPETITE FOR 1 MONTH. HE HAS A HISTORY OF DRY COUGH AND JOINT PAIN, FOR WHICH HE TAKES ALBUTEROL AND ASPIRIN AS NEEDED. HE HAS SMOKED 2 PACKS OF CIGARETTES DAILY FOR 15 YEARS. HE DOES NOT DRINK ALCOHOL. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION SHOWS A LINEAR, ERYTHEMATOUS LESION ON THE RIGHT ANTERIOR CHEST WALL, THROUGH WHICH A CORD-LIKE STRUCTURE CAN BE PALPATED. THE LUNGS ARE CLEAR TO AUSCULTATION. THE ABDOMEN IS SOFT, NONTENDER, AND NON-DISTENDED. EXAMINATION OF THE LEGS IS NORMAL. AN ULTRASOUND OF THE LEGS SHOWS NO ABNORMALITIES.
question: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS THE MOST APPROPRIATE NEXT STEP IN DIAGNOSIS OF THE UNDERLYING CONDITION?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have tender, red nodules that appeared on my chest 3 days ago.
Have these nodules appeared anywhere else on your body, or just on your chest?
Yes, three weeks ago, I had similar symptoms in my right lower limb and another episode in my left foot.
Do these nodules open and drain, or do they simply fade over time?
They resolved spontaneously without opening or draining.
Do you have any associated symptoms like fever, joint pain, or eye irritation?
I have joint pain, but no mention of fever or eye irritation.
Do you have any chronic diseases like inflammatory bowel disease, arthritis, or a recent history of infections?
I have a history of dry cough and joint pain, but no mention of inflammatory bowel disease or recent infections.
Have you had any recent changes to your medications, or started taking any new drugs?
No, I have not started taking any new drugs; I continue to take albuterol and aspirin as needed.
Final Diagnosis: Erythema nodosum.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient reports tender, red nodules that appeared on their chest 3 days ago. The patient experienced similar symptoms on their right lower limb three weeks ago and another episode on their left foot, both of which resolved spontaneously without opening or draining. Accompanying these symptoms, the patient also experiences joint pain. However, there is no mention of fever or eye irritation. The patient has a history of dry cough and chronic joint pain but no history of inflammatory bowel disease or recent infections. The patient has not started taking any new medications and continues to use albuterol and aspirin as needed.
trial_0.summarized_frq: Order an ANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies) test.
